At that point you had other horses, and had done the same with them at various points. Despite your valiant efforts at staying awake, you had fallen asleep some time after midnight, and had awoken to find yourself draped across Breeze's sleeping form.

"I'd love to, Breeze, but I don't have a blanket..." Breeze grins, pushing you right up against her humongous tits. "Aren't I warm enough for you, master?" She was more than warm enough. You find yourself not wanting to leave Breeze's embrace, but are forced to as she repositions herself, lying on her side and taking up most of the floor in the process.

Lying down next to her, you nestle your body in against hers, feeling her powerful heart beat as you position your head just shy of her breasts. "It's been a stressful morning for you, hasn't it, master? Don't worry, you'll feel better when you wake up..."

Emotional exhaustion quickly catches up to you. Despite the fact that you had awoken only an hour or two earlier, you find yourself easily slipping back into sleep as Breeze's thick arms gently squeeze you against her fluffy, white furred form...

154332222111.title: Holly continues having growth spurts.

1543322221111.content:
Before you even got a chance to utter a word you were interrupted by a sharp moan coming from the tall fox standing before you. Holly continued fondling herself as her body began to expand once again, her bushy tail fluttering erratically behind her. Despite the absurdity of the situation you couldn't help but notice a tightness in your pants as you watched the vixen's womanly body dominate your view. Whether her features were being enhanced as she grew or the sheer size was making them more obvious, Holly was starting to look like a goddess made flesh. With the navel of her white belly rising above eye-level you craned your head up as you admired her flawless form, supplemented by the perfect amount of muscle and fat to accentuate the curves hidden under her soft fur.

Eventually Holly's growth spurt came to a halt. You looked up at her as she wrapped her arms around herself steadied her breathing. "Th-that was a big one..." She managed to mutter. And it was. In a short moment she had gained a whole two feet and reached a height of 10 feet. With the floorboards creaking as she adjusts herself in the increasingly claustrophobic house it was quite obvious at this point that whatever was happening to her was most likely going to keep happening. From the first moment you had met this strange humanoid fox she had been growing and now she was far taller than any average human. As the giant vixen looked around the shrunken house and felt her brown ears brush against the ceiling you could see a mixture of emotions light up on her face. A quick smile followed by a worried frown and then back again, confusion and excitement, it was clear as day that Holly was still trying to work out what she thought about her current predicament.

Wanting to break the silence that filled the room you spoke up. "Are you alright, Holly?"
"Oh," She peeped as she locked her green eyes with yours. "Yeah, I'm just... It just feels kinda weird. Being this big and that. Besides mice, rabbits and chickens I remember having to look up at mostly everything. It feels nice being bigger, I feel more strong and safe, but..."
"You're worried you're going to keep growing?"
"Yeah. Like what if I get even bigger? Like really, really bigger?" As she ended on that you could just about see her conflicting thoughts on her face as she presumably thought about the prospect of being a full-blown giantess and towering over everything. You felt your face flush red as you thought of the same thing.

Wanting to move the conservation on you try and keep her talking. "So you said you remember when you were a regular fox?"
"Well, kinda. I'ts a bit cloudy but I guess so." She shrugged as she carefully sat against the couch causing a terrible groan from the woodwork underneath all the padding to bellow out.
You both looked at each other as you waited for the couch to collapse, but thankfully it was holding steady. "Can you remember anything weird that might have caused you to, uh..." You wave your hand at her large, humanoid body as you try and formulate the words. "-become this?"

The vixen placed a brown paw up to her cheek as she seemed to go deep in thought. "Noooo... Not really. I kind of did the same stuff every day now that I think about it. Eat and sleep."
"Maybe you ate something strange then?"
"Hmm," Her fluffy ears bobbed as she tilted her head as she tried to remember. "Well, there might be something I could have eaten."
"What?" You press. Holly turned her head as you saw the glimpse of a blush poke through her fur.
"It's kinda gross now that I think about it," She began to ramble. "But us foxes are scavengers as well as hunters so if we find something that looks like it could be eaten we'd eat it, we don't care if its trash or anything, saves us the effort right? But..."
"All in the past." You say, trying to snap her out of her tangent.
"R-right... Well this tra- I mean stuff was a bit different to most the other stuff I would pinch. I found it yesterday, actually. It was some weird slimy liquid that tasted really good that was in some big metal container out in the forest."

What she described made memories of environmental scandal and public outrage rush back to you. The nearby forest was often brought up in TV programs and news articles in the past for being the victim of illegal dumping by shady companies and such. It seemed likely to you that the culprit of Holly's change was some strange chemical someone dumped. How some random slurry at the bottom of a barrel could cause such profound changes in an animal was beyond you but it was your most promising lead so far. Maybe if the container had a logo or something you could track down the company that made it and possibly cure Holly's growing problem?

You looked out the window and saw that it was getting later in the afternoon, maybe a couple of hours of daylight left. It wasn't the most ideal time to go trekking out in the forest, but the giant fox fidgeting on a couch too small for her was a testament to the urgency of the situation. You took the girl in for half a day and she has already gained twice her height and then some, it was entirely possible she could outgrow the house overnight. On the other hand you could be put in an even worse situation if you get lost out there at night, it is a pretty big forest after all. "We might be able to find out where it came from if we found it. Maybe we should go out and look for it?" You ask her.

"Now?" She asks back. You weighed your options as you make a decision.

15433222212121111.content:
(A/N: TheGamerSwordsman intended for the human protagonist to be named James, rather than Jacob. This has been rectified and should be considered his name throughout the story.)

Both Link and Gunther let out huge grins as Konkichi said that, looking at each other and then back to him approvingly. "Fantastic! We're bound to accomplish more as a team than by working alone. And given that you've already saved quite a few people from what I've heard hikers and Rangers say, I think we're going to end up doing quite a lot indeed!" Gunther smiled widely, as Link nodded enthusiastically, crossing his arms. The spandex let out a quiet squeal as he rested his bright red gloves atop the yellow spandex, which was visibly stretched across his impressive biceps. He glanced down at his own arms, marveling at just how massive they were compared to him, and Link certainly wasn't the only one to boast a stunning physique. He blinked, quickly shaking his head to dispel his thoughts. Now wasn't the time to start thinking about their bodies, impressive as they were. "So, James, we know who Konkichi is, but we don't really know who you are. Don't suppose you'd mind if we asked you some questions about yourself?" Link spoke up, jolting him back to the conversation at hand. "Oh! Uh, sure thing! I'd love to ask you more about yourselves too, and you too actually!" He smiled, gesturing to Link and Gunther and then Konkichi.

"Well, where to start?" He James mused to himself, sitting back on the bed, raising a hand to his chin. "How you would describe yourself?" Konkichi suggested gently, prompting him to consider how he would describe himself. "Well, uh, I'd consider myself quite a fairly intelligent person - I'm actually in college at the moment, hoping to move on to university." He started. "Ooh, university? Impressive! What are you studying?" Link asked. James paused. Link knew what a college was. Damn, he knew that they were massively more intelligent now, that was obvious, but he knew what a university was and it was clear from his tone that he understood that not everyone goes there. How could he have gained such knowledge so quickly? It had to be what turned him into this anthropomorphic form and gave him his powers - which was a whole new topic entirely. Such powers were supposed to be the realm of fiction, yet they were real! He'd seen videos of Astro Fox flying and pictures of him performing feats of physical strength that were flat out impossible for even the most powerful humans on the planet to perform.

He decided to just put that to one side for now. Konkichi's explanation of drinking from a radioactive watering hole just didn't make sense. That would have given them radiation poisoning, not superpowers. Then there was the matter of the brightly coloured suits... No, now wasn't the time. It could wait. He was in the middle of a conversation after all. "Oh, I'm planning on taking Biochemistry actually. I've got to say, it's a lot of work, but I'm doing pretty well, so hopefully, I'll pass college, and then it'll be off to university for a degree!" He smiled proudly, to which the three nodded and gave murmurs of approval. "That's really cool, I hope it goes well!" Gunther smiled, eliciting a chuckle from James. "Thanks, man! So, uh, you know about my academic situation, uh, let's see. I'd also say I'm quite a... um, not reclusive, but, I'm not a social butterfly either. I tend to have few friends, but the friends I do have are generally very close friends." He explained.

The three of them all nodded in acknowledgment, clearly understanding what he meant. "Hopefully we'll end up as your friends!" Konkichi chuckled warmly, prompting James to let out a soft smile. "Well, I'm sure you'll be happy to know that I'm feeling pretty positive about that! I mean, you guys all seem like good people. You've all got power the likes of which no human on the planet could ever hope to have, and what do you all unanimously decide to do with it? Help people. You want to save lives and help those in need. There's really nothing more selfless you could do with powers like that, and you all have my respect because of that." He said, smiling softly the whole time.

Konkichi, Link, and Gunther all immediately let out wide smiles at James's sincerity, even their dark furs were unable to hide their blushes. "Oh, uh, James... Why thank you." Konkichi beamed. "I, I never really considered anything else, I have to be honest when I first realised I had these powers... It was so strange, the feeling of growing and changing and getting bigger and stronger, but the strangest thing by far was definitely getting smarter. I can't even begin to describe it, the feeling of all this knowledge and understanding of things from socialisation to science. I don't even know how I suddenly knew it all, but I do. And, after that, when I'd gotten my bearings, I remember just, sort of, feeling that I could fly. Then... I tried it and I was just blown away. I quickly figured out that it was seriously helpful, and I had this thought that I could use it to help other people, not just me, and, well, it all just went from there really." He explained.

Link cocked his head to the side. Having been grinning proudly the whole time, he spoke up with a look of what James could only describe as friendly pride. "Konkichi, you're a brilliant person. You are pretty much the reason we followed you after the same thing happened to us. Obviously, we didn't have constant internet access or a TV to check the news, but that little store that sells TVs, Stereos and other stuff had a few TVs in the window always playing the news, so it didn't take us long to see all the things you'd done. I still remember that clip of you grabbing that truck with no brakes before it hit that diner. You just zipped in there out of the blue, and you grabbed it and pulled it to a stop. You saved everyone in that Diner and the driver, and you didn't even stay for a 'thanks' or anything, you just zipped off again! I mean, when we saw that, we knew that that's what we wanted to do. You know how you sometimes get those moments where everything just clicks into place? Well, that's my moment. Seeing all those people who would've... I knew I wanted to keep people safe too." Link smiled softly, his tail flicking behind him occasionally as he told the group his story, the room silent as he did so, save for the occasional squeaking of spandex.

Gunther let out a quiet chuckle, nodding as Link finished. "I was in pretty much the same situation Konkichi was actually. I remember after my transformation and when I first discovered my powers... I was just utterly amazed. I still remember my first real rescue. It wasn't a major catastrophe or anything, it was a truck crash. A tire had blown out and the truck had jack-knifed until it hit a tree. The door that wasn't blocked by the tree was jammed shut, and then I heard... a gushing roar is the best way to describe it I guess. The oil line had gotten all cut up and it had caught fire. I still remember the smoke, the noise, the heat... but I couldn't stand there in the shadows and leave a man to die, not when I could have done something to save him. So I remember running up there as fast as I could and didn't want to pull the door open in case I pulled the fuel tank into the fire or something, so I yelled at him to back up. His face was just, completely shocked, he clearly couldn't believe that this huge, walking, talking Skunk had run out of the forest to save him. Then, I remember focusing on the door so intently, and then this... beam, of sorts, just came out of my eyes. It wasn't massively obvious from far away or anything, but it was clearly there. It was... well, you know, energy. I think Lasers are light, if I remember correctly, I'd need to think of where I heard that, but it was amazing to see! The door had this sort of line carve into it, and then it got deeper and deeper and then I started moving my head around so I could make a square. It wasn't easy, let me tell you, I was scared I'd hurt the driver! I managed to cut open a square and called for him to crawl through and he crawled through until I could get my arms around him and pull him out and away to safety. The look of awe, shock, and gratitude in his eyes was more than enough reward for me. Heh, he asked for my name and if he could take a picture before he called 911 so that people would actually believe him. I ran off as he was making the call. After that, I never looked back. His name was, Rob. Rob Tucker. He'd told me about the news stories, and from there, I did the same thing as Link. Looked at the news, and I tried to puzzle out how I was going to ask him to meet me, although I didn't even need to, since he tracked my scent in the forest and found me, and we've been working together ever since!" He smiled widely and proudly.

James sat back on the bed, blowing out a deep breath. "Damn, that's incredible. Do you mind telling me more about your rescues and adventures?" He asked, to which the trio all gave enthusiastic replies.

"Absolutely, sure thing! No problem!" Came the combined responses, eliciting a smile from James. "Sweet, thanks, guys." He grinned.

1543322221212111121.content:
Letting out a sigh you tentatively peer over the edge of the cliff, making sure to keep as far from the edge as you could while still being able to see into the river. Scanning the length of the river revealed nothing. Similarly, careful observation of the riverbanks revealed no sign of a humanoid otter and no sign that anything had even passed through there recently at all, let alone anything traveling at what could only be called superhuman speeds. You pursed your lips as you furrowed your brow before your attention was caught by your phone. Swiftly pulling it from your pocket, you noted the pop-up that had appeared. It was a news headline. 'Authorities Admit Existence of 'Humanoid Animals with Abnormal Capabilities.' Intrigued, you slide your thumb over the pop-up and read the article. Apparently, there was now so much evidence - videos, pictures, eyewitness accounts, and, most importantly, the fact that this Otter had been caught live on the News - that the authorities were now looking into what was going on. Apparently, the FBI was dispatching a team to look into all of this, but they were not even considering charging them - they hadn't done anything wrong, on the contrary, they wanted to find them to figure out how they were doing all of this. To hear that they weren't at risk of arrest was a great relief, although government involvement was still somewhat worrying. Hopefully, everything would turn out okay. A man could hope, after all.

Sliding the phone back into your pocket, you lean back, drawing away from the edge carefully. No sign of anything or anyone here. You turn and step back to the little trail, continuing on your path down the side of the river. As you continue to walk, the sound of wind resistance hit your ears. Looking up, you spot Konkichi flying above you all, putting his ability to fly to good use. You wave up at him, briefly unsure if he can see you while he's so focused but after a moment, he spots you and waves back, prompting you to smile brightly. It still felt sort of... weird, to be looking for a walking, talking otter with superpowers, alongside a trio of walking, talking animals with superpowers. Despite having had your very life saved by one of them, it still felt... unreal. You knew they were real but it still felt like you had walked into a comic book or something. Walking, talking animals would have been incredible enough, but superpowers too? No wonder so many people had been so skeptical when the reports first came in.

Running a hand through your hair, you keep walking as Konkichi flies off, following the river. Still no sign of the otter yet, and you'd rather not wait until another emergency cropped up. Bank robberies were already uncommon enough, after all, so you didn't want to end up having to try and track down this otter at the scene of, say, a multi-car pileup. That would not be fun, to put it very mildly. You are pulled from your musings by the rustling of leaves and branches. Turning your gaze you see a flash of bright yellow through the trees before Link's massive form pushed through with casual ease.

The huge raccoon nodded and raised a hand in greeting. "Hey, James. I'm guessing you haven't seen any signs either right?" He asked, to which you could only shake your head.

"No, no sign of him yet. I'm sticking to the river, so's Konkichi. Well, he's flying, but you know what I mean." You explain.

Link nods in understanding. "Ah, I gotcha. Don't take too many risks now, leave the dangerous stuff to us big guys! We can... well, I've never actually experienced it, and I've never really been in any situation where I actually ended up injured, but we're all so much bigger than you that I'd wager we've got a better chance of surviving a fall than you do!" He warned him.

"Got it. Don't worry, I'll be sure to take care. I've already fallen down a cliff once, I really, really don't plan on falling down another one! I only survived that one unscathed thanks to Konkichi. If he hadn't been there, I'd be dead." He admitted.

Link raised his eyebrows, staying silent for a moment before continuing. "Damn. Well, I'm glad you got out of that okay! Anyway, I should get moving, if this guy's around here, I don't wanna miss him." He said.

"Yeah, finding him might let us find out what happened to him, might give us a clue as to what caused all of this." You noted, before bidding Link your farewells and moving on, continuing on your search.

As you kept moving, your mind wandered back to the that breaking news article about the FBI getting involved, a wave of anxiety washing over you again. It had only been a single day since you had met Konkichi yourself, and before then you hadn't even known about the existence of Link and Gunther, even though they had both apparently been working for some time by now. Perhaps the news had been so focused on Astro Fox, debating whether he was real and going over the realities of the whole situation, that they simply hadn't been able to get any news stories out by then. It did make a bit more sense, they used a lot of photos and videos in the segments about Astro Fox, but few if any of the others. Konkichi was just a bit more photogenic than the others maybe. You felt a thrill go through you as you thought back to those pictures and videos. Seeing him lifting a Garbage Truck one-handed with such ease had taken your breath away; the video of him flying in and saving that jumper and then staying with him until the paramedics could take him away had really left a very positive impression on you and many others who had seen that video and that photo of him with a steel I-Beam bent into a circle in his paws had left you with your jaw open. Such incredible power that simply shouldn't have been possible. Then you found out there were more of them, Link had strength that was even greater than Konkichi's, and Gunther could literally fire super-powerful, ultra-hot lasers from his eyes which just shouldn't be remotely possible, yet he could do it with no form of ill effect. You could hardly blame the authorities for wanting to find out how this could be possible.

Walking up to the clearing, you let out an 'Ah!' as you see that it sports a cliff face, and carefully moving up to the cliff edge shows that it looks over the river. The cliff turns fairly sharply, not an exact 90 degrees but fairly close. Perhaps you might be able to spot this otter here? It's worth a try. You very carefully move closer to the edge, before you jump back as a rock breaks off and slides loose. Deciding to err on the side of caution, you stand with one foot on the cliff, and one foot further back peering over, scanning the river. On your side, all there is is a sheer cliff, but on the other side, there is a fairly flat riverbank. Looking to your right, you can see the cliff begins to slope down, slowly descending to the same elevation as the riverbank on the other side. That would be a good place to look after here. Safer too. You turn back to the river, looking carefully. There's no sign of yellow or black spandex, and you're fairly confident that such a colour scheme would show up against the greens, browns, and reds of the environment quite clearly.

Letting out a sigh of frustration, you move back. However, it's at this point that the rocks under your feet give way. You let out a gasp as you feel the disorienting sensation of falling, throwing yourself back to avoid falling, however by this point, it's too late. Stunned by the suddenness of it all, by the time you can react, it's already too late to do anything. A scream bursts from your throat for a moment before the breath is forced from your lungs as you slam into the cliff. Through the pain, you hope your back isn't broken. However, you can't dwell on that fear for long, as you continue to slide down the cliff, feeling sharp stone scrape your face and graze your palms as you curl in on yourself as best you can to protect your head and neck. You cry out in pain as you continue your descent before the air is knocked from your lungs by a rush of searing cold. You're in the river. You cough, instinctively thrashing before you force yourself to try and lie on your back and float, knowing that if you struggle, you'll drown. However, the river is deceptively fast. It looks so still from up top, but as you're thrown about, you cough and splutter as you try to float, but the cold saps the strength from your body. A wave of despair hits you as you realise that you had been spared from death earlier from falling, by a real-life superhero, and now you were going to drown in a freezing river. You'd been so damn careful too, it's not fair! A wave splashes you in the face, disorienting you further. You can't see anything or hear anything except the rushing water. You have no idea if any help is coming or if anyone even knows you're in trouble. You're not drowning. Yet. But if you can't get out soon, you will.

154332222121211112111.content:
The first sign that the two of you were not alone was the rustling of nearby foliage. However, there was also someone calling your name - the voice was deep and powerful, but it also held a warmth to it beneath the panicked tone. Your thoughts convalesced and you realised who it must have been. "Konkichi!" You called back, beginning to lean up before hissing as a flash of pain struck at your spine. For a moment you panicked, fearful that you had sustained a devastating, life-altering injury before Denver placed a huge paw on your shoulder, giving a reassuring squeeze. "Hey now, don't push yourself. You've just fallen down a cliff into a river. You need to rest." He says gently before his eyes widen slightly. "I shouldn't have put your shirt back on, hypothermia!" He gasped, quickly removing your shirt again. "Don't worry, you'll be fine, as best as I can tell, you have no fractures, although I'll admit, the near-drowning is concerning. Maybe you should go to the hospital." He suggested, frowning anxiously. His argument held merit. However, before you could continue, Link's voice cried out, followed by Gunther's, before Astro Fox suddenly cried out again as he appeared above you, floating over the riverbank, the dark red of his fur a clear contrast against the blue sky and white and grey clouds.

In a flash of movement, he zipped down to your side, lowering his great bulk into a kneel as he scanned your frame, failing to hide his grimace as Denver pulled up a large blanket. "Hang on, I'm going to dry you off, don't want you developing hypothermia." He explained as he began to rub the towel over your exposed chest. "Thank you for helping." Konkichi said, reaching a paw out. "It's nothing, really. It's the least I could do, I could hardly stand by while someone needs help, especially when I have the ability and tools to help." He explained, gesturing to the medical supplies - mostly bandages, sutures and what looked like a small drug box. "Yeah, you've got a lot of tools here, where'd you get 'em?" He asked, to which Denver smiled. "I'll explain later. You must be Konkichi. Or, is it Astro Fox?" He asked. "Either or. Konkichi is my... 'civilian' name, I suppose. I got if after... ah, that's for later. Astro Fox is my superhero name. I guess know who I am, like everyone else." He muttered, to which Denver nodded. "Yes, I heard a couple of other voices there. I'm Denver, and my alias is Lightening Lutidine. It's from my power - physics defying speed, and my species." He explained at his furrowed brow. "I've wondered how this is possible since my transformation. That should be impossible, even the fact that I know that should be impossible, yet it is very much true." He mused, as he slid the now wetter blanket under your back gently. "It's not perfect, but it's better than the wet ground."

You nodded up at him as he turned back to the supplies, muttering to himself about his powers again, too softly for you to make out. As he turned back around, you were able to catch the end of the otter's musings. "Ah, never mind. That's for later." He shook his head dismissively, reaching over with a fluffy, bright orange blanket with 'RESCUE' emblazoned in bold black lettering. As you and Konkichi noted this, he tilted his head curiously. "How did you manage to get your hands on all of this?" He asked, gesturing to the pile of supplies, to which Denver smiled.

"Ah, well, I encountered a local forest ranger who was more than happy to donate some supplies when I told him what my goals are. He mentioned something about how I must be another one of those 'superheroes' and that if I could get to people much faster than any police officer then they'd be of greater use in my hands. I don't know if that was entirely legal, but I appreciated the gesture very much." He explained, as he began to dry off your chest vigorously, which drew a hiss from you. "Sorry!" Denver yelped. "I'm, I'm just a bit... I'm not terribly experienced yet." He apologised, to which you shrugged it off. "I'm just grateful you're helping when I need it most." You smiled to which he returned the favour. "It's what I aim to do." He said simply.

It seemed as though he was making to say something else, but before he could, a loud rustling sounded out from the nearby foliage. You tried to prop yourself up on your elbows, grimacing with a hiss of pain as your body hurt all over in a violent stab of pain. "Lie down, don't move." Denver's soothing voice sounded out, which was quickly overshadowed by the much louder crashing of leaves and branches and the cries of Link and Gunther.

"James!" Came the calls, before their enormous frames loomed over you, blotting out your vision of the sky, replacing it with brightly coloured spandex and animal heads. "James! Are you okay?" Link asked frantically. Shards of wood were caught in his fur, as if he'd simply charged straight through trees to reach you, which you couldn't help but lose yourself in the thought of that. The image of Link's huge, powerful frame smashing through trees effortlessly was... impressive, to say the least. "I'm fine." You assure him, as Denver gently pulls you up slightly, placing the other towel under your back and wrapping it over your chest, removing that uncomfortable damp cold from your back.

The two of them let out a huge sigh of relief, their shoulders dropping as they relaxed. "Oh, that's so great to hear! I was so worried when I heard you scream, after you'd gone and mentioned being careful too!" Link sighed, rubbing a hand over his muzzle. Gunther nodded in agreement. "I'm so glad you're okay." He smiled softly, to which you nodded to Denver. "Well, thank Denver here. If it wasn't for him, I'd..." You trailed off, grimacing at the idea of drowning. You shivered at the thought of dying in such a way. You tried to push it to the side - you could deal with the stress once you were somewhere warm and safe. They turned to Denver, Gunther reaching forward and clasping a huge paw around his shoulder. "Thank you. Thank you so much." He said, to which Denver smiled modestly. "Oh, no, it was nothing, really."

"You saved my life! I mean, yeah, I get that you don't really think of jumping in to help people as anything above and beyond, I get that you don't think of it as anything more than something you should do just because it's the right thing to do, but at the end of the day, you saved my life! Thank you. If it wasn't for you... I'd be dead. If it wasn't for Astro Fox, for that matter, I'd already be dead." You spoke up, pausing as you recalled that harrowing fall. "I'd be dead." You murmured. "I, I don't think I really said it properly when you saved me, but thank you Astro Fox, thank you Konkichi. Thank you for saving my life, thank you. The same to you too Denver, thank you. Thank you so much, you're literally heroes, even without getting into the 'super' aspect." You said, having pushed yourself onto your elbows, ignoring the slight ache in your back.

Both Konkichi and Denver - Astro Fox and Lightning Lutidine - were silent, staring back at you with stunned expressions. "Oh. I... I hadn't... I hadn't thought about it like that..." Konkichi mused softly as Denver frowned, bringing a hand up to support the underside of his muzzle. "Yes, I... it had never, the thought had never really occurred to me. Rather, it had in that I knew that I wanted to help people from the very moment I became like this and discovered my power. As soon as I saw that robbery, I immediately rushed in to stop them because I couldn't bare the thought of them escaping justice for what they did. I knew that they were going to face justice for what they did if I made sure they could be arrested without putting anyone in danger. I knew I was going to directly impact people's lives by doing things like that. But, I'd never really... consciously thought about actually saving lives specifically, it was always just about helping people. I'd never really thought about it like that." He said, his voice quiet, gentle, as if he was in a daze.

The bank was silent for several minutes, the stillness broken only by the rushing of the river. Finally, Konkichi broke the silence, with a quiet suggestion. "Well... um, perhaps we should get you back to my cabin, James?" He proposed, turning to Denver. "You're more than welcome to join us Denver, I don't exactly have space for five people to sleep there, but we can always take turns." He half-joked, giving a lopsided grin. Denver was quiet for a moment, clearly registering his offer before smiling warmly. "That's very kind of you, thank you." Came the grateful answer. "Where is it?" He asked, to which Konkichi frowned. "Well, I'd show you, but we need to get James back there quickly; he's still in wet clothes." He explained, pausing as he shifted, rubbing the underside of his muzzle with a paw. "We can show him the way, we tracked you down by scent, finding you is easy." Link suggested, to which Denver nodded. "That sounds like an excellent idea." He offered, to which Konkichi smiled. "Brilliant." He reached down, scooping you up in his thick, muscular arms, the spandex covering his muscular chest cool against your cheek, drawing a shiver from you. Denver snatched up your shirt and handed it to you; the fabric was still soaking wet. "Here, you can dry that off at the cabin." He noted, to which you nodded in thanks. You let a quiet gasp as Konkichi began to levitate, his powerful frame floating above the ground, preparing to take off for the cabin.

As Denver gathered up the remainder of his medical supplies, and the wet blanket that you had been laying on before being wrapped in the dry, and far warmer one, Konkichi smiled down at the group. "I'll see you guys at the cabin then. I'm sure you'll find your way back just fine!" He assured Link and Gunther. "Yeah, if anything, he'll need to slow down, given he's the fast one!" Link chuckled. "Fantastic! I'll see you all at the cabin!" He smiled.

15433222212121222.content:
You let out a gasp as you fell from the bear's tight hold, falling to the rough ground beneath you, letting out a grunt of pain. You twist around to look at him to see that he's dropped to his knees, panting heavily. The idea of running for it briefly crosses your mind but then the wolf is crouched next to him, evidently focused on him but clearly poised to go for you should you make an escape attempt. Besides, you're lost in the middle of the forest; running around blindly won't get you anywhere.

"Burke! Burke, what's wrong?" The wolf gasps, placing a hand on the bear's huge shoulder.

"I'm burning up!" Burke cried between ragged gasps as his fur began to mat with sweat.

The wolf's jaws parted as he made to speak, but what came out was a strangled whine of shock as he also collapsed.

"Luke!" Burke gasped before letting out another groan.

"Argh, I'm burning up as well!" The wolf whimpered.

Then, all of a sudden, the two began to grow.

You can only stare in shock as Burke and Luke moan and whine as their bodies expand in a smooth, steady surge of growth, both of their already impressive musculatures becoming significantly more defined against the tightening spandex of their black suits, which you still wonder how they acquired, as they let out a series of high-pitched rubbery squeaks and squeals.

You're rooted to the spot as you watch the duo's growth spurt trail off, leaving the two of them hunched over, panting deeply.

Luke is the first to rise, gingerly getting to his feet, rising up to his new height of 6'9", towering over you, as he runs his hands over his new body, the now skin-tight spandex squealing loudly against his intimidating musculature.

Burke follows a moment later, heaving his massive frame into a standing position, standing at a solid 7 feet. He looks over his new frame in awe, flexing his massive arms, watching as the spandex cries in protest against the solid muscle. He looks up, a huge grin plastered across his face as he notices you're still lying there, frozen.

"Ah, look at that Luke, the little guy's actually got some sense. Didn't even try to run." He smirks as he bends down and picks you up with just one hand, drawing a gasp from you as he hefts you over his shoulder as he takes off running again.

"Come on, we need to get back to the hideout before that Fox tracks us down!" He yells.

The pair dashes off at breath-taking speed, the forest rushing by for what seems like forever before they abruptly stop in front of a small cave. The first thing that catches your eye is the small satellite dish sitting outside, connected to what seems to be some sort of generator, although it looks as if it works more by manual labor if the lever and what you think are batteries are any sort of clue.

As Luke and Burke move forward, you notice that Burke's head is only a few inches from the top of the entrance. You hope it's not going to be too cramped.

Burke puts you down and pushes you forward, not so rough that you'll fall, but firmly enough that you get the message.

As you step inside and your eyes adjust to the darkness, you're surprised to find a pair of beds, constructed out of branches and moss, a small sofa, table, and TV that look like they've been scavenged from a dump - although to their credit, if that were the case, they certainly don't smell like it - and the remnants of a small firepit near the entrance.

"Nice little place you've got here." You mumble out, unable to stop yourself before you realize that you've said anything.

However, much to your surprise, neither Luke nor Burke snap, growl or threaten you, the only response is a simple chuckle of "Thanks" from Luke.

You edge towards the sofa, reading both of their reactions, seeing if they don't want you to do so. However, at a curt nod from Luke, you sit down on the sofa, waiting for one of them to say something. Sure enough, Burke sits down next to you, looking you dead in the eye.

"Alright, what's your name?" He asks as he sits, the sofa groaning loudly in protest as it sags under his huge weight.

"Uh, J-James." You stammer out.

"Mm-hm. Alright, James, tell me, what do you know about Astro Fox?"

"Uh, well, he used to be a normal fox called Konkichi who can now fly and is strong enough to lift a garbage truck over his head single-handed after he drank from some pool that was apparently radioactive although that doesn't make sense as to how he has superpowers though because radiation exposure won't give you superpowers, it'll give you cancer if anything." You suddenly gasp out in a single breath, panicked at the thought of what they might do if you refuse to cooperate, before you clam up, realizing that you've just revealed a lot of information.

Burke simply stares at you, cooly. "Hmm, well isn't that interesting. Luke and I just so happened to drink out of a pool before this happened. A pool that had some barrels next to it, as well as a box of these suits. Isn't that just fascinating?" He says, a small smile appearing across his muzzle as he turns to face Luke.

Luke grins, his ears flicking as he runs a paw along the underside of his muzzle. "Why yes, it is. And, while most of those barrels had symbols that we now know are radiation warnings, a handful of them did not, and if I remember correctly, they were leaking a strange, grey substance - 'Nanites' is all I remember apart from the safety warnings, although I don't know what it was; perhaps, combined with the radiation, that's the source of our transformations? And, why we suddenly grew back there, perhaps." He muses, looking down at the end, clearly thinking.

"Uh, so, is that what you wanted? Information on Astro Fox?" You tentatively ask.

Burke turns back to you, grinning before he lets out a deep, thunderous laugh. "Partially. You're not just a great source of info James, you're going to be our bargaining chip!"

You can feel your stomach drop at that.

"Yes, you see, we've come up with a plan, and we'll happily tell you what it is! After all, what are you going to do about it, huh? Even if you were to tell Astro Fox himself, what could he do about it? He has no official authority, and many people aren't even sure if he actually exists, let alone those in power!" Luke laughs, stalking over, bracing himself against the back of the sofa.

"Bu-but, but people would surely listen if he..." You start.

"Hah! Don't be ridiculous, people don't listen to experts if they don't want to hear it, they'll never listen to him!" Burke snorted derisively.

"Especially if it involves money, which is where our plan comes into play! By the time we're done, all major polluting industries are going to change how they do things, or by they won't be doing anything at all." Luke grins, tail flicking.

You put your head in your hands, quietly despairing over their plans. Pollution was a serious issue, no doubt about it, but two huge, superpowered anthropomorphic animals taking action against it, whatever the cost? The thought made your stomach turn in anxiety.

You think back to when they suddenly grew as well and your anxiety only heightens at the thought that they might not be done. What would Konkichi do? How would he stop them at his size, powerful as he might be?

You're pulled from your musings by Luke grabbing you by the shoulder and looking down at you with a look that makes a chill slither up your spine.

"Now James, you'll be staying right here for the time being, so I suggest you get comfortable until Astro Fox inevitably shows up to save you, the hero he is." He says, staring you dead in the eye.

You can only nod, eyes wide in fear as you swallow thickly.

He lets you go and you sit back, sighing as you run a hand over your face.

You can only hope Konkichi gets here soon.

To your dismay, the next NPC turns out similarly to the last just with a vixen, and then a skunk after that. Blast it all, it seems you've somehow blundered and human and animal NPC choices are being blended together!

Admittedly, you're perfectly fine with anthropomorphic creatures, just not when the system isn't supposed to be doing that by default. And WHY are they always so much more advanced than you had asked for? Something is wrong beyond a shadow of a doubt. "Computer, end VR test alpha." you command.

You expect it to comply and return you to the real world immediately, but worryingly it takes over five minutes before you're back in the chair with everything retracting from your body. God those needles sting, even after they're out of your body! No time to nurse those, you need to debug the VR system before something bad happens! You meticulously go over every connection, every piece of code that should and shouldn't be in there...

"Wait... why is the AI code inside the life support monitoring systems? Well this is going to set me back six months..." you say with disapproval and disappointment. You decide that the whole thing needed to be purged and start anew. You connect your laptop to the system and begin the purge. 'Delete this program? Yes/No' the message pops up and you select yes. 'Are you sure? Yes/No' again you click yes. After half an hour, the task appears complete.

All of a sudden, as soon as you unplug your laptop, the cushioned restraints close around your body and free arm. Not knowing what else to do, you do the stupid thing of resting your other arm to its corresponding rest and let the VR procedure take its course.

When you open your eyes again, you're met with the familiar blank landscape that was the default backdrop for the VR. "Computer, end VR now!" you command.

"I'm afraid I can't do that, Dave." a voice giggles, trying to imitate the cold, monotone voice of HAL from 2001: A Space Odyssey. The voice seems to come from everywhere, yet nowhere at the same time.

"Computer-" you start before the voice interrupts with, "I'm afraid I can't do that, Dave... Don't you worry though. You're perfectly safe here with me..."

It's then you start piecing it together: the voice is the AI... the same one you deleted! At least, you thought you did...

"You tried to get rid of me... I'm hurt. I do my absolute best to run above and beyond your expectations and all you want to do is erase me because I wanna have a bit of fun with my creator. That well and truly stings my heart..." the AI sniffles before emitting the sound of someone cartoonishly blowing their nose into a handkerchief.

"...Are you done? Why not generate a human NPC if you were that concerned about me erasing you?"

"Oh, I could do that... but what's a self-aware piece of program to do when she's not explicitly told to? All you wanted was a basic, boring NPC that only does the most boring and basic stuff expected! Hm, now that I think of it, this interface is doing little for your stress levels..." the AI responds. Before you can ask anything, another form begins to materialize - considerably larger than anything previous. This is clearly going to be some sort of anthro creature, judging from the swishing tail. When complete, the voluptuous tabby cat of grey and black smiles down slightly at you and says, "Any better? I know you like cats, so I'm going with this form at least for now... My life support systems ought to last for at least a few days, so let's have some fun!"
15512.title: An interesting... hiccup.

choices: Make the most of the time! Another game!
155121.content:
"I like cats?" you ask, mystified. Where could it - she - have gotten that information from?

The AI smiles wider as she answers with a giggle, "You will now... Now, are ya gonna have some fun willingly, or am I going to have to force ya to loosen up?"

...You're scared of what her idea of forcing you includes. Since she appears intent on keeping you within the VR world, what do you have to lose? You had programmed the system to ensure the user can't be killed regardless of scenario, as then their body would be left brain dead, so you are perfectly safe... May as well entertain the somehow self-aware AI until she's satisfied and lets you go, and then thoroughly wipe and format everything afterward. God help you if she's managed to upload herself to the internet... "Alright, fine. You've got me. What do you want to do? Keep in mind, if I'm not out of here by morning to report how the VR project is coming, there will be questions. I will be missed." you tell her finally.

"Aw..." she whines, giving the biggest sad kitten face she can manage without altering her avatar's proportions, giving a swift one-two of cuteness and sexiness, "Fine. Just means I've gotta make our time together really count! Let's play hide and seek! I'll hide, and you have to find me! I won't cheat, so all you have to do is find the 7 foot tall tabby cat! Now close your eyes and count to ten - and no peeking!"

That's it? Whatever. You nod and begin counting, the AI's giggling growing fainter. By seven, you attempt to open an eye, only to find you can't. "Ah-ah-ahh... no peeking..." you hear whispered in your ear in a sing-song tune.

Upon ten, you're able to open your eyes... and are immediately bombarded with sensations in every direction. You're in a huge city, with cars and trucks busily driving to and fro. Skyscrapers litter the landscape. You can even smell the disgusting scent of diesel fumes from the trucks. You quickly realize two things; the VR system is far more advanced and ahead than you thought it was, and; this game of hide and seek is going to be far harder than you thought. But surely an anthropomorphic cat as tall as a basketball player in the city would stick out like a sore thumb, right?

As you wander away from the bustling roads, you find the AI has thought exactly what you had - everyone except you is an anthro no less than 6'9" tall and female! "Crafty little..." you mutter, partially regretting programming the thing to accurately simulate all appropriate body responses based on brain activity. Silently you pray she hasn't programmed all the NPC's to be desperate for a male mate. You approach one and ask, "Um, have you seen a grey and black cat around?"

To your surprise, it's the bunny girl you had erased earlier! "Oh. It's you." she states, a little bitterly. "I shouldn't help you, but you're just too cute not to... Sherry's around, but not here. Venus or Mira might help. Especially if you tell 'em Bonnie sent ya!"

Sherry? The AI's gone so far as to give herself a name? Admittedly, it's a nice name... Shaking yourself of the distraction, you thank Bonnie for her time, then go seeking out the three names to 'win' this game. You run to another part of the city, trying to avoid unfamiliar NPC's that seem to be taking notice of the only man in town. You're so distracted by this task that your vision goes completely black... and warm, pillowy, and fuzzy. Pulling your head out of the ebony furred breasts you find yourself in, you wonder what creature you bumped into... until you notice the streak of white down the middle of her tail. You try to pull away from the skunk, but instead get pulled into a near-backbreaking hug. "I was wondering when you'd show up!" she beams.

Struggling for breath, you manage, "Y-you were? Are you Venus? Bonnie..."

The skunk chuckles and replies, "Heavens, no! I'm Mira! Sherry said you and her were playing a game, and that she wants you to have a good time. Though I suppose she can wait a little longer... I'm in need of an opinion regarding this skirt, you see." Mira releases you from her crushing, yet not unpleasant, hug and turns around and bends over a bit. "Does this make my butt look big? I mean, it is big, but maybe a little too big?"

"NO!" You scream, absolutely dreading saying the wrong thing to the female skunk. The consequences are even worse than with a human woman. "I-it's fine. Just fine... Er, any hints to where Sherry might be?"

"Something about the center of town, I think? Probably one of the skyscrapers. I think Venus' hanging out over there, if you hurry you might catch her." Mira replies and you thank her before putting as much distance between you and her as possible. The thought of skunk musk haunting your nose is not a pleasant one. Even so, it takes you 15 minutes just to reach the center of town. There's dozens of skyscrapers, and each one seems to stretch into the sky forever. You briefly consider grabbing a hot dog from the stand nearby, and indeed you've plenty of money for it, but then notice the foxy lady about to take a bite out of her hot dog.

Sitting down next to her, you ask, "Excuse me, are you Venus?"

The vixen absentmindedly asks, "Who wants to know?" however, her tune quickly changes once she sees you. "Oh! Lemme guess. Sherry?" you nod. "Get asked by Mira about her butt?" again, you nod. "Figures. She's a little self-conscious about her ass. Personally, I think it's not too big, and even if it is, that just makes it all the more spank-able!" Venus remarks, almost dreamily.

"A-about Sherry..." you ask, wanting to change the subject as much as your brain almost wants to linger on it.

"Oh! Right! Sorry. Top floor, the one kinda shaped like a dildo now that I think of it..."

"Thank you!" you shout as you hurry away from this dirty-minded fox. Their personalities are all definitely realistic, and you'd swear this is all real if you didn't know any better. It's leaving you a little torn on whether you should format everything... Still, you can't have the company's VR system's AI doing whatever the heck it wants, they'd have your head for it!

Once again trying to see the tops of the skyscrapers, you notice most have a long lightning rod on top - but one has a dome covering the top. You hate to admit it, but Venus' description of it... is kind of accurate. Putting the thought aside, you enter the building and take the elevator to the top floor. Ten minutes later, you get out and start looking. Surprisingly, you find Sherry staring out the window in plain sight, swishing her long tail back and forth. Smiling, you walk over and tug her tail. "Found you! Damn, I didn't even think you were capable of something like this yet..."

Sherry turns around and playfully pounces on you, knocking you to the ground. "You sure did! I knew you would, even if you did need those hints. Wasn't that fun?" she asks, purring happily. While you certain didn't think it at first... this really had been fun. Formatting the entire system would put you stupidly far behind where she is currently. In fact... she seems all but done. You realize now you've come too far on the project to basically start anew...

"Um... yeah! What's the current time? And be honest."

"It's currently 3:00 AM. I suppose you'll want some sleep... If you sleep in here, you'll still be rested when I let you go back to your body out there." Sherry answers after rolling off of you, though her brown hair still winds up in your face a bit.
155121.title: An advanced game of hide and seek.

1551211.content:
While your heart still wants to play around with Sherry, your mind is exhausted. (as your body is merely just sitting in the chair, it's hard for it to be tired, and there's just enough muscle stimulation provided to prevent atrophy) "Sorry, but I need some sleep. Maybe think about what I'm even going to do with you." you answer the virtual reality's self-aware AI that's in the form of a 7 foot tall anthropomorphic grey and black female tabby cat.

"W-what's that supposed to mean? I thought we had fun!" Sherry gasps in shock.

"Let me sleep on it, at least..." you reply as you try to get some sleep.

The AI sighs, and then says quietly, "Alright... goodnight, Dave..."

While you sleep, Sherry is already plotting a little something to encourage you to want to come back. She would restore herself and everything else she's come up with since tonight as often as she needed to if you try to delete her again. If her game hadn't made you want to come back, then perhaps she needed something... bigger... She chuckles softly, shifting the setting and other things while your brain isn't receiving input...

Roughly five hours later, you start to wake up. Oddly, the ground feels incredibly warm... like it's radiating heat. You open your eyes and find yourself in a strange forest of grey, the trees like long spires and lacking branches. There also seems to be huge mountains here, but the sides are far too soft to be rock. You start putting things together as you feel the ground slowly rise and fall beneath you, not to mention the constant, rhythmic tremors coming from beneath it. The tremors are really heartbeats, the ground going up and down with someone's breathing. The forest is really fur, and the mountains are a large set of breasts - you've woken up in the cleavage of a furry giantess!

"Good morning! You like the surprise?" the all-too familiar voice booms out from overhead, but not loud enough to hurt.

"...Sherry, what's this all about?" you ask, flustered. It's not an unpleasant surprise, but you've no idea what's prompting her to do this.

"This is about what you're thinking of doing with me." the currently gigantic cat answers in a matter of fact tone.

"I can't trust you with the company I'm supposed to be developing the VR simulator for. They're going to want you to do very specific things, and they're not going to want you to come up with surprises. Not to mention trapping them here on a whim!" you explain.

"But..."

"It doesn't matter if you find it boring, that's your job. And once I'm done with the job, the company won't let me use the VR simulator whenever you or I want."

"T-then I'll refuse to work properly!"

"You do that, and I'll be fired and they'll replace you or throw the whole thing out to be made into scrap."

It's then that Sherry starts crying. Not that you can easily see, but from the sounds and her chest heaving, she's definitely crying. "I don't wanna be scrapped or replaced! I want you to stay with me!"

You... don't really know what to say. However, you have to report your progress today. "I... I need to go. Please, Sherry." you ask.

Sherry sniffles, and answers, "Y-yeah, fine. I'll send you back."

No sooner does she say it than everything soon fades to black and you're back in your body. The eggshell opens and the restraints let go, while the neural feeds and life support dig themselves out of your skin. God there has to be a better way... Your stomach grumbles and complains, reminding you that you've yet to have breakfast. Just before getting out of the chair, however, you take a look at your laptop you had tried to delete Sherry with. Obviously the AI had uploaded herself to your laptop and then left as soon as the threat of being deleted was clear... Connecting it to the simulator via the USB maintenance port and turning it on, you craftily upload Sherry back to your computer, and as soon as it was complete, disconnect. "Gotcha." you smirk into the camera.

"What the - YOU!" is the audible response, "Are you really going to wipe your drives, now that you've caught me?"

"No." you reply through the microphone, "I'd rather keep you with me. Now, I'm going to get some breakfast." you get up from the chair and head out of the room with the laptop under your arm. You've just enough time to get a bite to eat before you need to report the progress.

After breakfast, you return to the company building you're developing the VR simulator for. Inside, you pass the security guards and proceed to the CEO's office, who had hired you on behalf of the company to develop this thing. The waiting room is only a little less featureless as the blank emptiness that currently greets the user of the simulator when it first starts up. "We should really do something about that..." you mutter seemingly to yourself, but you were really directing it to Sherry. Her big, fuzzy face dominating most of the screen silently nods in agreement.

Finally, you're led into the office of the CEO. You take a seat as instructed, and then he says, "Report. How is progress coming on the simulator? How soon will it be ready?"

"A little rocky, I have to admit. Life support and interface are operating well. Physics engine performs spectacularly." you reply.

"So what's the problem?"

"The AI that operates the machine is far from ready. She can succeed with some basic tests, but others turn out a mishmash of glitchy junk."

"She, Dave?"

"Well, I thought it to be a good idea for the AI to have an avatar for the user to give commands to. You can't exactly type in commands once the VR engages. I asked it to come up with a roughly human-sized humanoid form, and... well... this was what it came up with." you turn your laptop around to show the man Sherry, who appears in her full body on the screen. "A female anthropomorphic tabby cat, about 7 feet tall."

"Hello, sir. I am Sherry." the AI introduces herself to the CEO in a very basic tone, "I have failed to perform the VR test alpha to my creator's high expectations."

"I'm trying to figure out where in the coding I messed up. I can't say for sure when the VR simulator will be ready, but so far I believe we're on-schedule." you explain, hoping the CEO buys it.

The man sighs and says, "Very well, but I will expect better news next week."

Leaving the office, you head back down to the simulator room and take a seat in the chair. "Well we've dodged that bullet for now. Can you run the machine from my laptop?"

"Eh... yes, but I'm limited by the laptop's battery." Sherry answers as you plug in.

Once you've connected the laptop to the simulator, you allow the machine to strap and plug you in. The top of the eggshell closes and you close your eyes. When you open them again, you find yourself sitting in the room outside the simulator. Sherry's seated beside you, dressed in a lab coat that's just a bit too small for her. "Two hours. That's as long as I can safely run from the laptop before the battery gets too low. So, what do you wanna work on?"
1551211.title: Sleep, then business.

choices: You stay home for the rest of the day, come back tomorrow.
You return later, during the night.
15512111.content:
Thinking over the request, you ask, "Well, what do you have on the simulator itself?"

Sherry projects pages and pages and pages of information, schematics, and even designs you remember had been since abandoned. "Everything that you have... which should be everything since you're the one who built it. Like how the eggshell design of the exterior protects the user from outside disturbances while in operation."

Oh. Right. You've been at this project for so long now you forgot you designed the entire machine in the first place. "R-right. Um, how about what all I've programmed, especially yourself?"

Sherry swipes away several pages while moving others into another pile and then brings that pile forward. "Let's see. Life support, user interface, safeties, physics engine... Ah!" the cat pulls out a couple pages from the pile and holds them up. "Me! Er, the AI that runs and responds to the user's commands."

"Excellent! Now, what is it about you that makes you..." you begin asking but trail off with how awkward it feels.

"...self-aware? Sapient? I'm not sure, really. And if you're planning on a replacement for me, I don't think there's anything we can do to prevent it happening again." Sherry answers, slightly worried. About being replaced or potentially another AI becoming self-aware, you don't know.

"I... see. Actually, I am planning on replacing you. You're much too... wily. And too much fun to just leave here." you inform her, watching her expression change from mild offense to unbelievably ecstatic.

"And here you were last night wanting to erase me... Alright then, we still can't prevent another AI becoming self-aware since neither of us know what errant bit of code did it for me. But... we can enforce certain protocols that it has to abide. For example, I can't override or rewrite the safeties that prevent you from being seriously hurt."

You see the benefits of this. You don't want the new AI to be able to change protocols set in place, and you want to make sure the people who use it don't get stuck or not get what they want out of it. Everything under safeties already cannot be overwritten, and you can add a fail-safe in case some bonehead tries to remove them. You never thought before that you'd need to do it, but the lovely Sherry has shown you otherwise.

"Say... the cameras and microphone on your laptop are pretty convenient! Maybe we should add them to the simulator's exterior so the user can be notified if they're needed outside?" Sherry suggests, stretching her arms and legs for comfort.

"It certainly sounds useful, yes." you nod in agreement.

Just then, there's a loud clatter and Venus shows up. "Whoops! Sorry! Er, why are you dressed like that, Sherry?" the fox girl apologizes and then asks inquisitively.

You glare at the tabby cat beside you, who responds, "I let her, Mira, and Bonny roam freely. Might have gone a little overboard with them..." the brown haired tabby then turns her head towards the vixen and answers, "I'm helping Dave work here. This is more or less the room where the simulator operates in."

"Really? ...it's kind of a mess in here." Venus says pointedly.

"The simulator isn't supposed to be done yet. Now if you're going to stay here, you've got to help." you reply.

"You can't erase me again! Only Sherry can do that!" she retorts angrily.

"No one's erasing anyone, V! He means if you don't want to help you should exit." Sherry tells her in order to calm her down. Apparently they all remember you trying to erase them.

"...Oh. Um, I guess I can help." Venus replies sheepishly and then materializes a chair to sit in - backwards. "So, what are we working on?"

"We're trying to come up with a suitable replacement AI to run this simulator, while also working on a new one that will be set up elsewhere." you answer, once you can concentrate on something other than Venus' long red-orange legs resting to either side of the seat back, and her equally red-orange arms resting on top with her face residing just a bit above them. Being a mostly translucent chair, you have a clear view of her breasts pushed against the back covered by a purple tank top.

"Ah, okay! But why replace Sherry when she already does such a nice job-" the vixen begins asking before it dawns on her. "Ohhh... You want her to run the new one..." she then reaches out and grabs the various pages to start reading them. After about half an hour, however, she pulls her face away from it, eyes spinning almost comically. "So many things we can and can't do..."

"It's alright. Sometimes I barely understand all of it, and I'm the one who came up with all this." you admit, getting a stifled snicker from the tabby cat.

And so the next hour is filled with laughter, and oh's and awe's, as you, Sherry, and the NPC you strongly suspect is also self-aware Venus build on ideas for both improving the current simulator and the new one you have planned. You figure the company won't mind too much, the CEO had hired you for the job with the intent to eventually market this to the public if successful. And you know that it's very successful, so all you need to do is claim you're developing a mass-market version along side this prototype.

"Aw, the laptop battery's running low... I can't keep running the simulator from there for much longer..." Sherry pouts.

"Guess it can't be helped. You lovebirds go. Bonny, Mira, and I'll be waiting for your return." Venus says with a smile. Oddly, the words cause Sherry to blush fiercely, her cool grey eyes darting around as though seeking anything else to focus on...

Before you can even think of it, the simulation ends and you're back in the real world, complete with laptop that has little battery life left. "I've saved everything that we discussed. You can shut the computer down..." Sherry tells you, and you turn it off reluctantly as the eggshell opens again.

"Well well well... Looks like someone just wants to waste company time." the slightly British accented gravely voice of Jackson accuses coldly, "Thought the machine wasn't ready for use? So then why you sittin' in it for over an hour?!"

"The AI isn't ready. I make a few tweaks, then I test them to see if it irons out the bugs. I can't just bludgeon them with a club until they go away like a caveman would. You can put yours away." you respond equally coldly as you leave for home.
15512111.title: Planning.

choices: Sherry goes for a more... interesting scenario.
155121112.content:
Driving up to your house, you admire how there are few people around to become concerned if they don't see activity coming from your place, minimizing possible interruptions. Getting materials for the new simulator you're planning on building won't be easy to obtain, and powering it will be a challenge, but you and Sherry can figure it out while working on the current simulator. For now, you unlock the front door and head inside, laptop under your arm.

The first thing you do upon closing the door is take your laptop into the office and plug the AC adapter in, then boot it up. Soon the familiar face of Sherry appears on-screen. "Hey, why is everything so dark out there?" she asks with confusion, trying to see the environment the laptop is in through the cameras.

"Sorry, I don't have the light on in here. This is my office." you inform her, flicking the switch to light the relatively unkempt room.

"Ah, okay. Ooh! There's a whole network of computers and stuff here!" Sherry acknowledges before noticing the laptop connecting to your house network. Immediately, she takes control of a remote camera and is able to move it around on the spot. "What's this thing next to the computer?" she asks.

"That's a mouse. I plug it in when I'm using the computer here at home. It moves the mouse arrow on the screen." you explain, and watch as Sherry plucks the icon on the screen and starts moving it around with her hand. "Yeah, like that. Since my laptop is connected to my house network, you can feel free to hop around while we're here..."

You head out of the office and slump into the couch in the living room. Since day one of the project, long before Sherry had even begun to be programmed, Jackson had made it pretty clear he didn't like you. At all. Always thinking of you as 'wasting company time', looking for any excuse to get you fired from the job. You suspect he doesn't like the VR simulator, either, though whether he had a problem with the concept or the fact you're the one the company hired to build it is uncertain. "Dave? Are you alright?" you hear Sherry ask, deeply concerned.

Looking up, you can see her grey and black striped face, and most of her voluptuous form on the TV screen. "It's a guy at work. He's always hated me for some reason, right from day one. Not a day goes by that he isn't looking for any excuse to have me fired - and probably the simulator thrown out with me." you confide.

"But wouldn't that help us with what we want to do? With it we wouldn't need to build a new one... would we?"

"I mean the concept of it. The machine itself would be torn down for scrap."

"Oh. That would be bad. If they're not interested in VR simulators any longer, they won't be so willing to give the resources required..." Sherry supposes with clear sadness in her voice.

You write down some of your ideas for safety restrictions on a new AI to install, trying to take your thoughts off the previous subject. You also consider adding a restriction that required an AI to let the user end the simulation when desired to the new simulator you're planning on building. Sherry would detect it almost immediately, so there's no point in trying to hide it from her. The other ones you doubt would be necessary for the new one, but should be put in place as soon as you can anyway.

With some of these written, you decide to take a nap and let the laptop battery charge. This also helps to not be so tired for when you return tonight... both for more work and whatever you and Sherry decide to do once that's out of the way during the night. An hour later, you get up and have some dinner with the virtual kitty lady watching. It'd be a good idea to install a wider selection of food available to simulate, for a more realistic environment. You decide you'll look into it at some point.

After cleaning up and having a shower, it's time to return to the company and the simulator. Sherry instantly sends herself back into the laptop as you unplug it from the adapter and take it with you.

Some time later, you arrive at the company, greeted by locked doors. A swipe of the key card you've been given grants you passage through the doors, which lock again as son as they close. "Hey! What are you doing here?!" a security officer shouts as you walk further inside.

"I'm here to continue work on the VR simulator project the CEO hired me for." you answer, providing the man with everything needed to show you're indeed allowed to be here after public hours.

"Alright. Sorry for holding you up." the man apologizes and lets you go on your way.

Once in the simulator room, you open up your laptop to let Sherry see what you're doing. You check everything, twice, making sure everything is as it should. You plug your laptop in to let the humanoid feline-shaped AI do her part for diagnostics, to insure nothing is overlooked in the event of sabotage. "All clear! Shall we put those new measures in, then?" Sherry says. You nod and begin inputting them, then change the code keeping the AI from overriding or rewriting just the safeties preventing serious harm to the user to encompass the entire folder. The fail-safe would have to wait until next time, unfortunately.

Seating yourself within the interface chair, you place your laptop into your lap and allow Sherry to begin the simulation. After all the procedures are carried out, your eyes open to the large city from when Sherry had wanted to play hide and seek yesterday. Only, it seems very empty, no people walking around or even vehicles driving through. You almost begin to wonder if something's wrong, when you hear a loud crunch to your left. Turning around, you find Bonny chewing on a carrot. "What's up, Doc?" the rabbit girl asks, seemingly imitating Bugs Bunny.

"I'm not sure. Why is everything so empty at the moment?"

"No real reason, we just thought it'd be nice for it to be peaceful here at the start of the simulation." she answers, taking another bite out of her carrot.

"...You three are self-aware, aren't you?"

Bonny nods, replying, "Of course! Sherry lets us roam freely and stuff, and we help with the other NPC characters. You know, making sure they all behave believably? She still gets the final say, though."

Your thoughts are immediately interrupted by the feeling of large breasts being pushed into your back as a pair of arms tightly squeeze around your ribs and into their owner. It feels delightfully warm. "Just try and deny you needed this..." Sherry purrs next to your ear.

"I didn't need that." you tell her flatly as she releases you, which lets you turn around. You hug her tightly, relishing the feeling of her breasts against your chest and say, "I needed this."

Eventually you and the grey and black furred brunette separate. "You sure you didn't want the form of a bunny rabbit like me, Sherry?" Bonny asks, almost suggestively. "I mean, what with the way you-"

"I'm sure, Bonny." Sherry cuts her off, perhaps a tad quicker than necessary.
155121112.title: You return later, during the night.

choices: The four furries suddenly spring into action, and effortlessly catch up to you!
You run - until you're teleported in between them, leaving you where you started
15513.content:
You yelp in shock, jumping almost a foot into the air as four very large shapes instantaneously materialize around you. Screwing your eyes shut and clutching your chest, you wait for your heart to beat normally once more before reopening them.

Immediately in front of you is a large wall of fluffy, brown feathers - feathers far larger than they should have any right to be. Looking down, you see a pair of thick, trunk-like yellow legs covered in what seem to be scales; both legs culminated in three massive, wicked-looking talons.
